content.description:
This is on the left side of the wall and starts off a ledge 9ft off the ground which is nice and flat and convenient to flake your ropes out on. The first pitch is short and passes a little overlap before the anchor. The second pitch gets very easy once you reach the big juggy black knobs on the upper section.

Rappel with 2 ropes.

climbs.name: Smear Campaign
climbs.fa: Dan Dingle, David Whitelaw, Bob Steed, 10/07

content.description:
This was my favorite of the Cookie Sheet routes I've done so far. It is possibly the longest on the wall, reaching the highest point on the slab over on the right side. The route begins on the far right side of the highest ledge system, just before a drop-off.

The first pitch climbs through some 5.8 friction and then some small corners and features up to the anchor. The second pitch is hard for 20 ft right off the belay and has a tenuous clip at the first bolt. Have your belayer hanging out to the left so you don't fall on their head if you blow it. After that it's more cruising up to another anchor. The 3rd pitch works through some steeper (but still low-angle) bulges on featured rock and then climbs up a final slab to the anchor just below the headwall.

Slipstream takes a line of strength up gold polish on the far left side of the wall. There is only one bolted route to the left of it, Dark Side (5.7).

It is best climbed in one long pitch, but you can stop and hang out at an anchor half way up if you want. This intermediate anchor also allows you to rap with one rope, or set up a toprope on the first 90'.

I found the climb to be pretty sustained and one of the harder ones we did at the Cookie Sheet. If you've never heard sticky rubber "squeak", you will on this mirror like polish. After the final bolt, I traversed right to a featured corner which leads to the anchor. Bolts tend to be about 20ft apart on this one.

Plastic Jesus is in the middle of the Cookie Sheet. Scramble up 3rd class ledges near the left side of the wall and then traverse right on hummocks. Plastic Jesus starts from a sort of high point on the hummocks and climbs straight up to a sort of apex on the center of the wall.

The first pitch passes a small overlap just before the anchor. The second pitch climbs through some polished grey rock. The 3rd pitch is short and wanders a bit to the left. The second and third could possibly be linked with a 70m, but I'm not sure. The route felt kind of easy for 5.8 I thought, way easier than Slipstream.

Rappel with 2 ropes.

climbs.name: Eye Noir
climbs.fa: Bob Steed, Dan Dingle, David Whitelaw 4/08

content.description: starts on friction slab to ledge with 1" crack pro, followed by more bolted slab. A bit runout on all pitches, but bolts where it counts, and shiny new ones too.  Everything would be in the GREAT rating until you pass through a round dark grey cavity, "the eye" on P3. shortly after that, positve edges become slimy and covered in sometimes 1-2'' of bird or bat guano, which really spices up the finish, 15' above last bolt, trying to clear slimy footholds and handholds of a toxic goop. The belay is full of it, and you then find it comes from the large flake just above, on the upper headwall, where a lot of noise was happening at sunset in 1/12 when my girlfriend and I climbed it. Bring a brush or rap after pitch 2! Shame really, the Eye is cool.
content.protection:
4 bolts P1 +1" cam, 3b P2, 6b (and large scrub brush) P3

Great rap rings, bring 2 60m ropes, long p2&3
content.location: starts midway across the 3rd class right traverse ledge, just past a tree and near a nice small ledge to sit on.

climbs.name: Emm Too
climbs.fa: Dan Dingle, David Whitelaw, Suzy Dingle, 4/08

content.description: The rock on this climb is a little more gritty than most of the Cookie Sheet routes. Emm Too is the next climb over to the right of Wump World and requires a bit of 3rd class to reach the base. Easy terrain leads up to a big sickle shaped flake. Some .75 or 1" gear can be placed behind it. Climbing past one more bolt leads to the anchor. The second pitch is very runout and traverses left to join the top of Wump World. We didn't have a topo at the time and had no idea where the second pitch was supposed to go, so we rapped after the first.

P1 5.6, 4 bolts, 160'. P2 5.8+, 120', 4 bolts . abrupt crux from easy slab to steeper, slicker rock, moving up and foot traversing right on polished dike. Polished slab continues on first part of P3, but is well bolted, with 8 bolts on P3, 150'.
content.protection: 8 quickdraws, 2 ropes to rap from rings on all belay stations
content.location: 25' right of Eye Noir, 1st bolt up and right from small cluster of trees on approach ledge.

content.description: This is a bolted, nicely polished slab climb located to the left of Slipstream. Pretty sure it gets its name because it is more shaded than the rest of Cookie Sheet, in case you don't feel like baking in the sun. It's nice to set-up a TR at the anchors for Pitch 1 for climbers new to polished slab.
content.protection: There's 5 bolts on the 95' Pitch 1 leading to a 2-bolt anchor. Pitch 2 is shorter at 70' and easier (maybe 5.5). A couple of bolts and a finger-size piece (the pin that used to be there is gone) get you to the anchor.
content.location: After the gnarly scramble to the base of Cookie Sheet (must love a big talus pile!), Darkside is the first route on the far left side.
